intro: Gynoxys incana, commonly known as the hairy gynoxys, is a flowering plant native to Central and South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers that range in color from white to pink. It typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and stream banks. Gynoxys incana is often used in horticulture for its ornamental value and can thrive in well-drained soil with partial to full shade.
